title: How popular is Eurovision in your country? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’m from Switzerland, and until last year the situation was like this: The ratings were quite good, better than the average Saturday night show, but comments on social media and online articles were mostly negative, like “Why do we even bother taking part of this, if we never qualify for the final anyway?” (Maybe we should try sending better songs …) “Even when we sent DJ Bobo in 2007 (who was very famous in Europe back then), he didn’t qualify” (Have you listened to the song, it’s not very good, is it?) “But it’s so political anyway” (What does that even mean?) “Eastern countries give each other points, so we have no chance” (Ahem, the majority of the winners since 2009 are from western Europe …) “But it’s so expensive” (it’s not much more expensive than producing our own four-hour entertainment show) “Our commentator is so bad” (He’s a bit plain, but definitely not bad. Besides, you can watch it on German or Austrian television, surely you’ll find a good commentator.) Thankfully, we finally produced a 4th-place entry this year, so a lot of this complaining is now obsolete. It will be interesting to see how it develops.

I come from Australia, and we, oh we just LOVE the Eurovision Song Contest. Mainly because most of us come from Europe and our grandfathers and grandmothers have watched it. This whole love story between Eurovision and Australia started in 1983, three years after Channel 0/28 (now SBS) started up. SBS, instead of broadcasting programs similar to the programs on other Australian channels at that time, broadcast programs from around the world, some of them in different languages. Anyways, in that year, SBS broadcast the 1983 contest in Munich delayed. I guess they figured that people on the other side of the world were watching them, so they read this message at the start of the program: “And a special welcome to our viewers in Australia”. Ever since then, millions of people have tuned in onto SBS to watch what’s going on over in the other side of the globe. In 1987, it kinda went up a notch. Johnny Logan won Eurovision ’87 in Brussels, and in case you didn’t know, he’s from Australia. So the people watching the contest in Ozm must have felt pretty proud. Then we switched it up AGAIN. From 1983 onwards, SBS would either broadcast the show with no commentary, or they would use the BBC’s tape, which features the voice of Terry Wogan. But, one year after the new millennium, SBS sent Effie Coustas to Copenhagen’01 to co-host alongside Terry Wogan in the booth. Two years later, Des Mangan took full advantage of the commentary for Riga ’03 and Istanbul ‘04. I think by then, people already realized Australia was watching them, so these Australian flags started popping up in the arena in 2007. Then Julia Zemiro was sent by SBS to commentate Belgrade ‘08. The next year (Moscow ‘09), Sam Pang was sent alongside Julia to commentate. It was like this up until Kyiv ‘17, two years after Australia made its debut in Vienna ‘15. Julia and Sam stepped down and were replaced by Joel Creasey and Myf Warhurst. They’ve been commentating ever since. In conclusion, Australia, we just love Eurovision.
